text: Moonlight. A magical forest of trees. Diamond shards of blue light on wrinkled, wormy roots. Over the mossy gorse steps -- A little TAILOR, with scissors, needles and thread hangin from his belt. A glass key round his neck. And a tall, grey hound beside him. He sees ahead -- A giant stone, where a crack opens up. The Tailor peers inside. And squeezes down inside a dark tunnel. Which leads out into --

A shimmering hall of phosphorescent light. The Tailor see a tall glass dome; and a shining glass coffin, on a velve pall, surrounded by moths and butterflies. The Tailor peers inside the glass dome, sees -- A miniature castle, with windows and battlements.
The Tailor peers in, to see: a sleeping PRINCESS, her breath ruffling her golden hair. In her hands: a box, lik a@ green ice egg.
The Tailor -- takes his glass key, slips it into the lock (CONTINUED)
... And the little tailor thought to bend and kiss her perfect cheek, because he knew this was what he must do...' And kisses the Princess. She opens her eyes, full of wonder.
You must be the one I have been waiting for. You must be the prince.
No, you are mistaken. I ama tailor. In search of work to keep me alive. The Princess laughs. And the sound of her laughter SHATTE the GLASS COFFIN into splinters. And on the box, CLOSE IN and --
... I am the resurrection and the life,' said Jesus. “He that believeth in me, though he were dead, yet shall he live...' SLOW FADE UP TO a silvery BLACK AND WHITE --

The box lies in the hands of a widow, MRS. ELLEN ASH, in front of a mausoleum. It's a dripping November day, sun l in the sky. Ellen lifts back her veil to kiss the box. Which she plac inside -- a wrought iron vault. Its doors close.

Let the body and soul of Randolph Henry Ash lie in eternal peace, mourned by his sorrowing widow Ellen... PULL BACK to see Ellen and mourners, men in black hats an cloaks like silk-clad ravens round an Egyptian-style vaul tomb. Ellen focuses on the box behind a metal grille. HOL ON -- the box. As before our eyes, the box and tomb rapidly -- (CONTINUED)
Age a hundred years. Roses wither and die. Moss, weeds, leaves, briars, tendrils of undergrowth push and coil ‘ro the grille.
honored not only by those of the year of our Lord 1888, but by all of time... And as a wind blows leaves, FADE UP TO --

The spinning wheel of a bicycle. The spokes blur in a constant motion, giving an illusion of stillness. As -- Suddenly VIVID COLOR and SHRIEK of CAR HORNS -- A young man weaves perilously ‘round a worm of traffic. I anorak and cycle clips, ROLAND MICHELL, thirtyish, dodges down back streets, cutting through into --
Roland wheels his bicycle to sheds, removes his clips. Oblivious to his trousers splashed by mud. He unpacks his bicycle panniers. Heads through a side entrance into!--
Roland walks down a long corridor, leading through to an ECHOING domed hall. He pauses by a party of TEACHER and school-kids in front of a statue of an eminent Victorian: Randolph Henry Ash.
Roland stares fondly up at the stern features of Ash gazi lifelessly out over the kids' bored faces.
Poet, philosopher, naturalist, statesman, Randolph Henry Ash was one of our most eminent literary heroes... (MORE) (CONTINUED)

‘ whose famous love poems to his wife Ellen are among the most glorious jewels of our literary heritage. From the Victorian age, only Browning and Tennyson --! (to unruly kids) Pay attention, Kylie --! Who stare amusedly at Roland's nerdy appearance, cycling helmet still on. He slips unnoticed down a side stair-wel entering --

Through a door marked, "Ash Institute: Director Professor James Blackadder." This is the "Ash Factory": <A basement of corridors, in institutional grot. Strip lighting, peeling paint-work. PAOLA, a fifty-something secretary with moth-like glasses glances up at Roland.
‘Morning, Roland. Blackadder's in a panic. Mortimer Cropper has landed.
Oh, God. Did Blackadder finish my reference? I asked him weeks ago.
I reminded him. But you know what he's like when Cropper's in town.
I must talk to Blackadder. He knows since he gave that job to Fergus...
Accident? Notices his ruined trousers, on her way to the photocopie
(hadn't noticed before) Oh... my bicycle, I suppose. (CONTINUED)
Roland puts down his panniers, squeezes past Paola into t pantry. He flicks on the kettle. Looks for his coffee mug
Who's been using my mug? As he unscrews the coffee jar, waiting for the kettle to boil, he turns to see at the door, a grey-haired woman, staring at him.
If you have a minute, Roland... This is Dr. BEATRICE NEST, doyenne of Ellen Ash studies a Keeper of the Ash Museum, an eccentric spinsterish schola
Actually, Beatrice, I was about to get started on those Ash footnotes!--!
It's important. It's about Ellen... Ominous silence. Roland registers Beatrice's insistence. She disappears down the hall. Roland has to follow her in
A musty cavern of cardboard boxes and yellowing papers. Behind them, almost bricked in, sits Beatrice. Who flings letter over to Roland.
I can't bear it. Another letter from that impossible woman, Leonora Stern. She wants a piece from me for some ghastly new journal about Ellen Ash's sexual relations --
With... Ash?
With anyone. This woman's obsessed with sex. (CONTINUED)
You protect Ellen from questionable suitors, Beatrice. I've always admired that.

Ellen was a faithful wife. And I'm faithful to her. She needs protection. I'm the only one now who cares... NOISES in the corridor. Two academics poke their noses in One, his rival, a trendy young lecturer, FERGUS WOLF; the other, a bluff elderly Scottish professor, JAMES BLACKADD Roland's boss.
Hi, Roland. Still here?
Fergus.. (beat) Congratulations on your appointment... Downcast, Roland shrinks back in defeat. Blackadder blusters in.
Ah, Roland... I want you at the London Library. Come along, Cropper's in town for the auction... Blackadder whisks Roland out from the room.
They walk down the corridor with Fergus, Blackadder putti on his coat.
I feel sorry for poor Beatrice. Even the feminists hate her now for championing a dull wife --
(exasperated) Beatrice Nest and her bloody letters of Ellen Ash are completely irrelevant to modern scholarship. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
She's wasted twenty-five years looking up every recipe for gooseberry jam and jaunt to Broadstairs. That's what I get for hiring a Ph.D from... (can barely say it) New Zealand.
The old witch. She's the best keeper of the Ash Museum you'll find

Yes. Like Ellen, Beatrice is best behind closed doors... Blackadder and Fergus swoop off. Roland watches them go, turns ‘round to see -- Beatrice scurry back into her room like a crab. Obviously overheard their comments. Roland sighs --
The spinning wheel. On his bicycle, with his panniers and clips, Roland swerves through noisy traffic, heading for

An elegant London square. Roland cycles in as leaves blow from a tall tree towards a vast Victorian library, where people leave by stone steps, armfuls of books. As Roland parks his bike -- Some LEAVES float away, tumble towards a skylight on the library roof TAPPING like birds trying to enter, as --
Roland enters the shabby hall. Bespectacled scholars shuffle around in a silent hum. Roland seems suddenly "at home." All around him, wasted lifetimes devoted to books.

Roland navigates like a mole accustomed to the dark throu amaze of metal shelves. Hidden stairs and tiny corridors like a Piranesi prison, books piled high: dark, dusty, infinite... Roland seems to know his way, even in the dark...

Zig-zagging through a labyrinth of books, Roland emerges down in the basement. He knocks at a door marked "Rare Books 5." No reply, so he enters -- A musty room like a pharaoh's tomb, a high window casting light into a cell of vellum and leather. Roland puts file down.

My name's Dr. Michell, Roland Michell. You have a copy of Donne's poetry for me. An 1858 edition. A pebble-glassed LIBRARIAN emerges, crooked as his totter piles of books. Slightly deaf, he takes his time.
You ordered it through Professor Blackadder over at the Ash Institute?
Correct. I'm working on the Complete Works edition with him.
I didn't know Ash was an admirer of Donne?

He quoted one of Donne's poems on his deathbed. I'm checking references in the Nineteenth Century editions... just to be sure. The Librarian finds Roland's book, bound with tape. He wipes away black dust, hands it over. Roland sits down, cracks pages apart. (CONTINUED)
Doesn't look like it's been touched for a while. I'll check... Flicking through, Roland sees notes scrawled in the margi
It intrigues him.
Someone's scrawled notes all over the margins.
Hm...? Well... it's never been called for, as far as I know... (checks file cards, as Roland reads) Odd... According to our records, this edition was bequeathed to us by Ash's widow, Ellen.
You mean this copy belonged to Ash himself? Someone must have consulted it before now.

Seems it was lost in our filing system... Intrigued, Roland goes back to cutting leaves. With great delicacy he cuts open a set of pages, suddenly two old letters fall to the floor. Roland bends down to pick them up --

(rambling on) . Devil and Demonology, Dogs, Domestic Servants and... Donne...' (beat) You can lose anything in here. I found a set of false teeth once... Roland isn't listening. Dazzled by a thin shaft of sunlight, Roland starts to read. On yellowing PAPER, a sound of a PEN SCRATCHING. (CONTINUED)
And Ash's voice -- deep, intimate -- OVER:
... Dear madam, Excuse this letter to a stranger. Yet since our pleasant and unexpected conversation at Crabb Robinson's party, I have thought of nothing else...'

On hearing Ash's voice, Roland turns the letters over. Li a spell, the voice stops. Roland stares hard at the letters, then looks back at the Librarian. Concealing the letters from view. Warily, Roland turns the letters over again. As Roland reads the next passage, his expression changes to wonder.

... I feel, I know with a certainty that cannot be mistaken, that you and I must speak again...' He reads on, silently. Then turns the letters over again. He folds back the book to the front paper: A signature "Randolph Henry Ash." Roland pulls the letter up beside t signature --
Incredible...
A match.
Like a great poker hand, Roland can't believe his luck. Suddenly alive, confused, palpitating, he looks ‘round.
Hm...? Found anything interesting?
deliberating. His heartbeat seems to pause. Time stops, his whole life converges in a single moment: Life or deat truth or lie, a simple "Yes" or "No":
No. Nothing really...  ll.
Guiltily, Roland slides the letters into his copy of Poems of R.H. Ash. And slips the book beneath his arm, as A loud KNOCKING sound CARRIES OVER from --
Sold once... sold twice...
A hammer bangs on a gavel as an AUCTIONEER closes a deal. In a panelled room, a crowd of buyers sit waiting, some poised on phones, others with catalogues: Victorian Literary Memorabilia.

Sold for a hundred and twenty-five thousand guineas... The tall, handsome buyer, acknowledges the Auctioneer: MORTIMER CROPPER, U.S. scholar, collector, master of the universe. Nearby, the elderly LORD ASH, and his wastrel son, HILDEBRAND.

... Letters and memorabilia of Randolph Henry Ash, including wedding rings belonging to the poet and his wife... to Professor Cropper. Behind him, Blackadder and Fergus Wolf exchange glances. Cropper acknowledges Blackadder, turns to Lord Ash.
We can rest easy, Lord Ash. The wedding rings are secured for the Ash Collection.
You beat the Japanese again?
Of course, sir. We have very ample funds.
(repeating vaguely) Very ample funds... Lord Ash smiles. Cropper comments to Hildebrand. (CONTINUED)
Pleased to see your father so happy.
Money always excites him.
Then we should go. No more buried treasure here. Your father's very frail.
But not frail enough. Envy in his voice, as Cropper collects the rings. He whee Lord Ash's chair to the exit. Blackadder and Fergus gossi
You have to hand it to Cropper, repackaging Ash as a New Victorian. All moral rigor and family values. Pure opportunism! --
Now Newsweek picked it up, the old goat thinks he'll get a Pulitzer for his book. Hideous... (beat) But I wouldn't trust anyone, faced with Cropper's loot... Blackadder rushes up to Cropper.
Congratulations, Professor Cropper.
Ah, Professor... Dr. Wolf... Look at these rings. Wonderful things... He proudly holds up the rings before them. All look on.
I remember when my father would amuse himself by placing the treasures of his own collection in my sweaty paw... (MORE) (CONTINUED)
(stroking his palm; sensuously) ‘ “Here, Morty, my boy,' he would say. “Here is history to hold in your hand.' Priceless...
Surely a strain even for your budget. Effortlessly superior, Cropper smiles condescendingly.
At the Cropper Foundation, we don't have a budget. Just a check book. Blackadder, Fergus watch him wheel Lord Ash out.
Roland rides up the lanes of rundown Stoke Newington. Outside a tall Victorian house, Roland stops, brings his bicycle up steps. Opens his doors, and enters --
Locking his bicycle in the hall, he picks up a pile of ma And wearily goes down the stairs into the basement.

Portraits of Randolph Henry Ash stare down at a kitchen table. CATS gather, MIAOWING for food, as -- VAL, his long-time girl friend, sets down before Roland a plate of lamb and ratatouille. It's reheated, and like their relationship, tepid, and potentially poisonous.
Shall I get a bottle of wine?
You should've thought of that before. Roland dutifully picks at the meat. Then -- (CONTINUED)
I made an amazing discovery today!--
It'll go cold.
I was in the London Library. I found Ash's own copy of Donne poems with all his notes in the margins. And I'm sure no one knew it was there --
I expect they didn't.
... If I tell Blackadder, I know he'll think it's important --
I expect he will. Roland sees the bad mood. Like a storm gathering strength
I'm sorry to bore you, Val. It does look exciting. I can write it up. It'll make me a better job prospect
There are no jobs. And if there are, they go to Fergus Wolf -- Val gets up from the table. Roland dutifully prods the lamb.
If you think what I do is so unimportant --

(lighting a cigarette) You do what turns you on. You have this thing about this dead man. Who had a thing about dead people. That's okay, but not everyone is very bothered about all that... (MORE) (CONTINUED)
(draws on cigarette) I see some things, from my menial vantage point in my lawyer's office. Last week, when Euan and I Roland starts to feed cats below the table.
Who...?
A lawyer. In my office... Oh, never mind. Val turns to him. At first slowly, calmly. Then louder...

I suppose I envy you, piecing together old Ash's world picture. Only where does that leave you, old mole? What's your world picture? And how are you ever going to afford to get us away from dripping cat- piss and being on top of one another?! Roland stares, stricken by Val's show of temper.
Something's upset you, hasn't it?
Seems a reasonable deduction.
Three A.M. Outside a dilapidated Victorian house, a breez RUSTLES through a tree's LEAVES. MOVE IN THROUGH a WINDOW where Val lies in bed, alone. Outside the bedroom --
Sitting on the lowered loo seat, Roland goes over the letters. He stares at the handwriting, hears Ash's voice. (CONTINUED)
. Dear Madam, Excuse this letter to a stranger...' RUSTLED by WIND, with a strange, harmonic MUSIC, the lett hover delicately in his hands. Haunted by Roland's...

As Ash escorts Ellen into the house, he carries on throug party, inside a conservatory of Oriental plants which conceal guests playing blind man's bluff. Ash sees a WOMA head turned away. ON that look --

Since our pleasant and unexpected conversation at Crabb Robinson's party, I have thought of nothing else...' Ash is drawn towards the Woman -- FREEZE ON his expressio his features turn as if to stone, as -- END OF DREAM.
Crisp pages of a yellowing volume. Roland reads the journ of Crabb Robinson. An entry under 1858.

June 18, 1858. My breakfast party went off very well indeed. I had with me: Mr. Bagehot, Mr. Ash, Mrs. Jameson... Professor Spear, Mrs. Lees, Miss La Motte and her friend Miss Glover, the last somewhat taciturn...' Roland locks up, scribbles a note: "Christabel La Motte." He dreamily sees --
In the conservatory, Ash, as before, walking towards a Woman, turned away from him (and us). (CONTINUED)
The host, CRABB ROBINSON, a mustachioed aesthete, observe his guests.

Ash had never met Miss La Motte, who spoke more forcefully than I expected. She is surprisingly handsome when animated...' In BLACK AND WHITE we see as distant shadows -- Ash with Woman -- Christabel La Motte -- and behind her, another Woman -- BLANCHE GLOVER, an attractive, but less confiden artist.

. We all discussed with Mrs. Lees her claim to have conversed with the spirit of Charlotte Bronte... Mr. Ash appealed to Miss La Motte on the question of visions and second sight; she declined to express an opinion, answering only with a Mona Lisa smile.' From Ash and Christabel's smile: Rapturous, intense... END _OF FLASHBACK.
as Roland double-underlines the name "Christabel La Motte He takes his slip of paper to --
Standing in a catalogue room, trousers still coiled by bicycle clips, Roland flicks through the cards in a gargantuan index. Under "L," he rummages until he finds t reference...
(mumbling) La... La... La... La Motte. (CONTINUED)
"La Motte, Christabel 1825-1890. Poet, critic."
jots down a reference: 719.640. Moves down to related literature. Roland holds a card at arm's length. From behind, a voice:
I didn't know you had an interest in Christabel La Motte... Roland turns, sees Fergus peering over his shoulder. Ferg reaches over to investigate the card. And laughs.
I don't. I never heard of her until now. (beat) Why did you laugh?

You're looking for an involuntary expert. There are two people in the world who know all about Christabel La Motte. One is Professor Leonora Stern from Tallahassee. The real expert is Doctor Maud Bailey at Lincoln. Cropper and I met them both in Paris. A conference on sexuality and textuality. (beat) A formidable pair... they have quite a thing together.
A “thing'?
I don't think they like men.
Oh, dear.
Maud runs a resource center up there in Lincoln. Cropper's funding it. They've got Christabel's papers there. If you want anything, that's where to look. (CONTINUED)
I might. Thanks. What's she like?
Unreadable. The feminists are interested in her. Wrote a poem about a fairy who married a mortal for a soul --
I meant Dr. Bailey... Will she eat me up? Fergus considers briefly. A lot of undecodable feeling.
She thicks men's blood with cold. ON Roland's look, a mix of intrigue and worry --

The beautiful face of MAUD BAILEY: pale and cool, like a marble statue. Blonde hair up, Maud stands in a doorway o a modern campus block, as past campus fountains and lawns Roland walks toward her. As he closes in, he is drawn in her beauty. He recognizes it, yet cannot even admit it. She is middle-class, beautiful, confident: everything he dare not aspire to.
You must be Dr. Michell?
Yes... Roland... Maud offers him her long, cool hand. Roland puts down his briefcase, shakes her hand.

I hope you haven't wasted your journey, Dr. Michell. With neither a word nor a smile, Maud turns, walks into t faculty building. Roland takes a step, remembers his briefcase. Turns back to pick it up, and has to -- Catch up with Maud, now several steps ahead, opening a do to --  20.
In a new building of beige wood and tinted glass, Maud wa with Roland towards an elevator. Young, punky female students walk past, rings in their noses, holding hands. Roland sees no men.
On the phone you said you found a connection between Randolph and Ash and one of my poets.
I found a draft of a letter in one of Ash's books. I thought it might be to Christabel La Motte.
What sort of letter?
A love letter, I think.
Hard to believe. Where's your evidence? Maud presses the button for the elevator. They wait.
There was a breakfast party, June 18, 1858. At the home of Crabb Robinson. I believe they met one another there --
You can never rely on Crabb Robinson. He was a notorious gossip, always inventing things... The ELEVATOR PINGS, opens doors. Maud and Roland step inside.
Of course, but he has some curious details...
Inside the elevator, Roland and Maud are uncomfortably cl together, as they go down into the resource center's basement. (CONTINUED)
el.
: He says Ash and Christabel discussed each other's poems. And met the spiritualist Mrs. Lees. It sounded plausible to me. In 1861, Ash wrote Mummy Possest after a seance --
My Christabel was interested in spiritualism. But I don't think Ash would have appealed to her. His poem is full of hatred for women --
Then it's probably a wild goose chase. As you said. (beat) I hope you don't think I've made all this up. This relationship --
You said connection.' Now it's a relationship?
Between two people. Two human beings. Isn't that normally called a relationship?
Depends. I think your theory is way off the mark. It sounds, frankly, a little bizarre. Maud turns away, heads off into the library. Roland follo her.
I need to cross-reference it with her journal. You did say Christabel kept a journal...
No. But we have a diary by a friend of Christabel. An artist, Blanche Glover...
Crabb Robinson mentions Miss Glover. Who was she? (CONTINUED)
Maud picks up interest. The ELEVATOR PINGS, doors open. They walk out of the elevator, towards the library doors.
Blanche was Christabel's housemate - - and most certainly her lover. In front of the doors, Roland hangs back. Maud holds the door open.
Am I allowed in?
Naturally.
On a desk, Maud brings out a box of musty manuscripts. Sh picks a single volume, places it on the desk in front of Roland. A thick, green, leather-bound notebook.

Blanche's diary was among Christabel's papers when she died. Leonora is looking for a grant to have it edited. She's found a researcher from France who's interested. But we can't go through everything...
Then I'll let you know what I find. Maud is about to go. She relents, giving in to her curiosity.

I checked my files before you arrived. Christabel only referred to Ash. In a letter she wrote to William Rosetti, towards the end of her life. (beat) It was... if anything... hostile. (beat) You have a couple of hours. Roland sits at a desk. Illuminated by a shaft of overhead light.  23.

A gilded dove, flying out from a keyhole. He opens the lavishly-illustrated book, with marbled endpapers. "A Journal of Our Home-Life In Our House in Richmond" By Blanche Glover Commenced on the day of our Setting up House May Ist, 1853." As Roland flicks to June 1858, her writing is decorated w pretty drawings, slowly merging into swirling, macabre images.

... June 18, 1858. We went out to breakfast at Mr. Crabb Robinson's home. Present were Mr. Bagehot, Mrs. Lees, Mr. Ash the poet, though without Mrs. Ash, who was indisposed...' In his mind's eye -- Roland tries to penetrate a misty cl
(SILVER NITRATE BLACK & WHITE) - DAY (1858)
In a garden conservatory, Ash moves towards a beautiful woman, back turned away from him. Behind her, as Ash draw closer is -- A woman, we now recognize as -- BLANCHE GLOVER.
'... The Princess was much admired and rightly...' Ash is intercepted by HELLA LEES, a spiritualist. Who introduces the beautiful woman: CHRISTABEL LA MOTTE, a beguiling pre-Raphaelite brunette.

'... She professed to like Mr. Ash's poem Ragnarok greatly. Which naturally flattered him...' Christabel returns Ash's smile. Modestly flirtatious, she is drawn into his orbit, staring deep into his eyes.
'... This famous poet would have been much surprised to know my true opinion...' (CONTINUED)
Blanche watches Ash walk with Christabel away from her.
'... But I smiled and nodded as best I might, keeping my thoughts to myself. (beat) I desired to be at home.' Blanche holds in her hand a book, with an embossed gilded dove on its cover. Then --
Checking the clock, flips through yellowing pages of Blanche's journal, filled with portraits of Christabel.

'... My Princess is much exercised about a long letter which arrived today, which she did not show me, but smiles over, and caught up and folded away...' Slowly her portraits change into macabre drawings of serpents and goblins. Roland returns to a page he's skimmed:
'... Letters, letters letters...'

In the hallway, a pile of letters. Christabel picks them up, heads upstairs. Followed at a distance, by Blanche: Her face brooding and suspicious. As Christabel drops a letter -- Blanche picks it up, goes to the door, confronts her with it. Christabel runs upstairs, sobbing...
'... Not for me. You need not hurry them away...'
Christabel hides letters in her sewing basket, folds them under handkerchieves. Outside, through the keyhole -- (CONTINUED)
'... I am no sneak, no Governess. From that fate you rescued me, my Princess, as I shall rescue you from yours...' Blanche spies in.
Her eye large, unblinking. Blanche moves back, stares out the window. The panes frame her face. A storm is beginning. By candlelight --
'... Now we have a prowler...' Blanche sees tree shadows move across windows. RAIN and WIND HOWL outside. WINDOW FRAMES RATTLE, Blanche's anger mounts. As branches scrape over windows --

'... I hear him out there. A wolf at the door...' Blanche watches as from outside something BANGS against a door. A low moan of CRACKING WOOD. A latch is BATTERED until ready to give. In a reflection, Blanche sees --

'... This peeping Tom has put his eye to our walls. Now he peers shamelessly in...! A man's face -- Ash -- BOOM! A sudden GUST OF WIND. Windows and shutters are blown in -- rain pours through. silhouette -- a face like Ash. Then the WINDOW BURSTS ope Splinters of glass fly towards Blanche --
Silence. Dusk has turned to night. Beneath an isolated pool of overhead light, Roland looks up from the diary in darkness. Among the shelves, a shadow stirs. From the darkness --
Did you find anything? (CONTINUED)
Maud steps into the light. Stunned, Roland closes the boo
I think so. Alone together in the deserted library. Unexpectedly intimate, even erotic. Maud perches on a desk.
Do you know about this prowler Blanche was so worried about? The wolf at the door?
You think it may have been Ash? You saw her drawings. Blanche had a vivid imagination. On the desk, Roland and Maud flick through Blanche's maca drawings of labial flowers and serpents' tongues.
And was jealous.
Possibly. If Christabel was her lover. Lovers do get jealous, don't they?
What happened to Blanche?
She drowned in the Thames, shortly after completing this book. Suicide. Christabel was distraught. It was all very sad. (beat) But it's getting late.
I need to find out what happened next.
Sorry, not tonight. The center's closed. Roland looks at Maud. Realizes now or never.
Then I'd better explain. (CONTINUED)
Roland takes out the two stolen letters from his pocket. tosses them on the table. Maud starts to read them.
I found these. They're in Ash's handwriting.
You're sure they're authentic?
I've checked. They're dated June 19, 1858.
The day after Crabb Robinson's party.

Precisely. If I can find something definite, they could change our whole idea of Ash. (beat) And perhaps of Christabel. Maud's pulse quickens. She finishes, looks up, regaining her composure. Senses their importance.
I haven't shown them to anyone else. No one else knows they exist. I found them in a book in the London Library.
You stole them -- ?

I don't think they're mine, or anything. But they're not Cropper's or Blackadder's or Lord Ash's either. Don't you see? My Ash lived a quiet and exemplary married life. Now, suddenly... (beat) A love letter to an unknown woman. As Roland ties himself in knots, Maud is coolly accusator
I suppose they might represent a considerable academic scoop. For you. (CONTINUED)
Well, I wanted to be the one who does the work... (realizes her insult) ... Wait a minute -- it wasn't like that.
I'm sorry. I'd never have the nerve to do that. Steal them...
It was an impulse. For the first time, I felt Ash was alive in those letters. It was incredible. That's why I need you to find out the truth about Ash and Christabel --
You know Cropper funds the center. If he finds out --
He won't. If you don't tell him.
I can't let you Xerox Blanche's diary. The spine won't stand it. Maybe you could copy it out. I need to think.
You can't throw me out.
Can I book you a guest room?
I don't have any money.
I thought you were working for Blackadder.
Part-time. I also wash dishes in a restaurant. Maud mulls it over. (CONTINUED)
You'd better come back to my place. (beat) You can sleep on my sofa. Roland looks at the diary. The traces of the faded brown writing. As Maud's hand rests close by.

Outside in the hall, Maud collects bedding, plays back an ANSWERING MACHINE MESSAGE from Cropper, as in her sitting room -- Photographers from Leonora, letters from the Cropper Foundation. An illustrated book has been left open for hi on her desk.
I found something for you. A first edition of Christabel's poem, The Fairy Melusina that Blanche illustrated...
Can I read it?

Yes. It's very beautiful. Critics still dismiss her poetry. But I always found it strange and powerful. There's one passage about a woman who'd give anything for a child, even a hedgehog, and duly gives birth to a monster... Roland looks at the macabre illustration. As Maud enters.
I think Blanche is sorry for the hedgehog.
Is she? (impressed by Roland's insight, Maud examines a picture) Yes, maybe you're right. Leonora thought it was related to Frankenstein, the product of Mary Shelley's horror of birth -- (CONTINUED)
Thanks. I'll read it. Perhaps it'll help me sleep... (realizing his mistake) I didn't mean it like that. Maud throws him blankets. Glares at him.

See you in the morning. There's a train every hour. Maud closes the door. Roland lies on the couch, listening to her in the next room. He settles down, picks up the bo of Christabel's poetry, starts to read. In shadowy darkne

EMERGE as the IRIS OPENS OUT INTO a strange dreamlike pla of Christabel's secret imagination: a dark, sinister fairyland where owls cry, wolves howl. Through an enchant silver forest -- A distant KNIGHT in armor dismounts his weary blood- spattered horse. Over, Christabel whispers her poem:

'... A draggled knight came riding through the trees, Behind him fear, before him darkest night...' The knight hears a song from a hollow chamber: Inside a glass coffin, bound by silver chains and sapphire ropes, lies a fairy princess in white silk. She holds a goblet u to the Knight:
